repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Sectoral and Pre-Investment
            Studies Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sectoral and
            Pre-Investment Studies Project for Rwanda were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, project sustainability was
            uncertain, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the need to frequently evaluate the
            appropriateness of the objectives, design and implementation
            arrangements of a technical assistance project, especially
            in situations of political and administrative instabilities.
            The need for strong supervision efforts, involving the use
            of specialized expertise, for broad multisectoral TA
            projects. Should the situation arise, as in this case, that
            a project cannot be adequately supervised, it should be cancelled.

docna.cdata!:
Rwanda - Sectoral And Pre-Investment Studies
            Project : Credit 1796 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Rwanda - Sectoral And
            Pre-Investment Studies Project : Credit 1796 - Credit
            Agreement - Conformed

repnme.cdata!: Rwanda - Sectoral and Preinvestment Studies Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sectoral and Pre-Investment Studies
            Project, an IDA project, aims to support the
            Government's objective to improve its
            investment/planning process by financing sector/subsector
            studies and feasibility studies for development projects. It
            seeks to help the Government (i) better define its
            development objectives and determine appropriate strategies
            to achieve them; (ii) continue to improve the quality of
            projects submitted for outside financing; and (iii)
            strengthen local project preparation capabilities. To this
            end, the project consists of (a) assistance to carry out
            sectoral and preinvestment studies; (b) training of selected
            staff in (i) the preparation, implementation and monitoring
            of a rolling Public Investment Program and (ii) project
            preparation and appraisal; (c) completion of the
            installation of a Documentation Center; and (d) logistical
            support related to the above. The project will result in
            preparation of sector strategies, production of a portfolio
            of well prepared projects ready for submission to financing
            sources and avoidance of unviable investments.
